LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
Borrower  Kingdom of Cambodia 
   
The Proposal  The  proposal  comprises  a  loan  equivalent  to  $10.0  million  for 
subprogram 3 of the Financial Sector Program II Cluster (FSP II). 
The  FSP  II,  approved  on  6  December  2007,  takes  a  cluster 
approach  and  consists  of  four  back-to-back  subprograms.  Each 
succeeding  subprogram  is to  be  processed  sequentially  upon 
completion of the preceding subprogram. 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Finance (finance sector development) 
Themes (subthemes): Economic growth (promoting economic 
efficiency and enabling business environment), governance 
(economic and financial governance) 
Location impact: National (high impact) 
   
Environment  Category C 
Assessment 
   
Social Sector  Involuntary resettlement: Category C 
Assessment  Impact on indigenous people: Category C 
No  involuntary  resettlement  or  impact  on  indigenous  people  is 
expected from program implementation. 
   
The Program   With a rapidly growing commercial economy that requires a sound 
Rationale    financial system to sustain its rate of growth, the Government needs 
to develop the financial sector by mobilizing financial resources—
channeling  them  to  productive  investments,  and  managing  the 
inherent risks—if it is to achieve long-term sustainable economic 
growth and poverty reduction. The Asian financial crisis of 1997–
1998  and  the  global  financial  crisis  that  began  in  2008  have 
provided many examples of the devastating impact that financial 
crises can have on countries, wiping out several years of growth 
within  a  very  short  time.  To  promote  economic  growth,  reduce 
poverty, and help countries prepare to mitigate shocks emanating 
from external financial crises, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
plays an important role in supporting financial sector development in 
its developing member countries, including Cambodia.  
 
The program loan cluster is supporting the Government’s continued 
efforts  to  strengthen  the  financial  sector  by  supporting  a 
combination  of  legal  and  regulatory  reforms,  targeted  capacity 
building, improved disclosure standards and financial transparency, 
and establishment of key financial infrastructure. A sound, efficient, 
and integrated financial system is crucial for achieving broad-based 
sustainable  economic  growth.  It  helps  to  reduce  poverty  by 
increasing job opportunities, lowering transaction costs of economic 
activities, and extending the outreach of the formal financial sector 
to poor and rural areas. An efficient financial system will promote 
private sector development and foreign direct investment. A robust

ii   
 
financial  sector  will  protect  the  economy  from  unfavorable 
exogenous  shocks,  which  are  becoming  more  common  in 
increasingly global financial markets.     
   
Objective and Scope  The FSP II aims to promote the development of a sound, market-
based  financial  system  to  support  resource  mobilization  and 
sustainable economic growth. With a growing, resilient, and more 
efficient financial system as the expected outcome, subprogram 3 
will continue the following reform activities: 
 
(i)  Improve financial intermediation by upgrading the payments, 
clearance, and settlement system to support growing financial 
services;  enhance  market  confidence  by  improving  public 
financial  disclosure  and  establishing  a  credit  information 
bureau;  support  market  development  by  establishing  an 
interbank  market  and  tradable  government  securities;  and 
improving the outreach of microfinance institutions (MFIs) in a 
sustainable manner.  
(ii)  Enhance  resilience  of  the  financial  sector  by  revising  and 
updating the law on banking and financial institutions, and by 
introducing  supportive  regulations  to  strengthen  financial 
activities;  tighten  prudential  supervision  and  regulations  of 
banks and microfinance institutions; and build on the legal and 
regulatory foundation by adopting a new law on commercial 
contracts  that  includes  specific  sections  on  agencies  and 
franchising. 
(iii)  Promote  good  governance  by  implementing  international 
initiatives on combating money laundering and the financing of 
terrorism,  by  enhancing  corporate  governance  and 
transparency  in  the  insurance  industry,  by  establishing 
commercial dispute resolution mechanisms, and by improving 
the capability and increasing the number of qualified national 
accountants and auditors. 
(iv)  Enhance  efficiency  by  computerizing  the  management 
information system of the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC), 
as well as by upgrading the skills and capacity of microfinance 
agencies’ staff.   
   
Loan Amount   A  loan  of  $10,000,000  equivalent  will  be  provided  from  ADB’s
and Terms  Special Funds resources for subprogram 3. The loan will have a 
  24-year term, including a grace period of 8 years. The interest rate 
  will be 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum 
thereafter.  
   
Program Period   The implementation period for subprogram 3 is January–December 
and Tranching  2009. The loan will be released in a single tranche upon completion 
of specific tranche conditions and following loan effectiveness. 
   
Counterpart Funds  The  Government  will  use  the  local  currency  counterpart  funds 
generated by the loan proceeds to meet program expenditures and 
associated costs of reform and additional budgetary allocation to 
help ease the effects of the global economic downturn.

iii 
Executing and  NBC will be the Executing Agency, and the Ministry of Economy and 
Implementing Agencies  Finance  (MEF)  and  Ministry  of  Commerce  (MOC)  will  be  the 
Implementing  Agencies.  The  financial  sector  steering  committee, 
chaired by the governor of NBC and comprising senior officers from 
MEF, MOC, and NBC, will meet as required to review progress 
reports from the technical working group, consider pending issues, 
and  propose  concrete  actions  to  resolve  issues.  A  senior  NBC 
officer has been appointed as program director to assist NBC, MEF, 
and MOC in coordinating day-to-day program implementation. The 
program director will submit quarterly progress reports to ADB on 
program implementation. 
   
Procurement  The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs  (excluding  local  duties  and  taxes)  of  items  produced  and 
procured in ADB member countries, excluding ineligible items and 
imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  All 
procurement of goods and services produced in, and originating 
from, ADB member countries will be made with due consideration to 
economy  and  efficiency,  in  accordance  with  standard  public 
procedures  in  Cambodia  and  normal  private  sector  commercial 
practices acceptable to ADB. In accordance with the provisions of 
ADB’s  Simplification  of  Disbursement  Procedures  and  Related 
Requirements for Program Loans (1998), the loan proceeds will be 
disbursed to the Kingdom of Cambodia as the Borrower.  
   
Risks and   Program implementation could face a number of risks, for which 
Safeguards  mitigation measures have been put in place, as appropriate.  
 
(i)  External  challenges  to  sustaining  economic  growth. 
Cambodia’s economic prospects must be viewed against a 
number of adverse developments in the external environment. 
The unexpected surge in international energy and food prices 
toward the end of 2007 fueled higher domestic inflation in the 
early  part  of  2008  with  knock-on  effects  on  consumption, 
growth,  and  poverty.  The  Government  introduced  a 
combination  of  fiscal  and  monetary  measures  to  moderate 
inflation, resulting in a slowdown in lending since late 2008. 
Falling  energy  and  commodity  prices  helped  to  ease  the 
inflation  rate,  which  reached  a  single  digit  in  early  2009. 
Although inflation was contained, other economic conditions 
were affected in the fourth quarter of 2008 because of the 
spillover effects of the financial crisis that originated in the 
United  States  and  Europe,  causing  the  global  economic 
slowdown.  The  global  economic  downturn  has  negatively 
affected Cambodia’s growth rate, as demand for Cambodia’s 
garments has reduced, tourist arrivals have fallen, and foreign 
investments  for  large-scale  construction  projects  have 
declined. As the garment, tourism, and construction industries 
are three of the four main drivers of growth, the economy is 
projected to slow down to –1.5% (from 2.5%) in 2009 from an 
estimated 6.7% in 2008. The Government has further eased

iv   
 
monetary  policy  since  February  2009.  The  fiscal  deficit  is 
forecast  to  be  above  the  2009  approved  budget  to  create 
space for fiscal stimulus. Because of uncertainty about the 
duration  of,  and  depth  of  impact  of  this  global  economic 
downturn, the Government and ADB will continue to undertake 
periodic  reviews  of  macroeconomic  and  financial 
developments to assess potential risks to the financial sector 
throughout subprogram 3. These reviews will continue through 
the  program  period  for  subprogram  4.  Budget  assistance 
through  program  loans  in  2009,  including  through  this 
program, is being provided to bolster the economy’s resilience. 
 
(ii)   Corruption and weak governance. Weak governance and 
incidents of corruption could erode investor confidence and 
prevent  the  attainment  of  expected  sector  outcomes.  The 
Government’s  National  Strategic  Development  Plan  2006–
2010 views corruption as a threat to sustained growth and 
development of the country in general. Backed by an active 
development  community,  the  Government  is  increasingly 
taking a tougher stance against corruption. The consensus is 
that good governance and measures to address corruption are 
needed for a successful partnership between the Government 
and the development community. This was considered during 
design of the program cluster, and there will be continuous 
pursuit  of  improvements  to  the  institutional  governance 
structure,  accounting  disclosure  standards,  financial 
transparency,  complementary  legislation,  regulatory  updates 
and enforcement, supervision, and surveillance of the financial 
sector.  
 
(iii)  Weak  institutional  and  human  capacity.  Some  of  the 
financial sector risks are associated with weak institutional and 
human capacity. The same applies to the implementation and 
enforcement of new laws and regulations. To mitigate those 
risks, training programs have been initiated at various training 
institutions  established  during  the  first  Financial  Sector 
Program.  Subprogram  3  provides  financial  support  to  the 
institutions to help update their curricula. The proposed TA 
that is being processed separately will help reduce the risks 
arising from weak capacity, especially in the implementation of 
all prudential regulations and in addressing new challenges 
emerging from the lower domestic growth caused by the global 
economic  downturn.  With  these  design  safeguards,  the 
integrated benefits and impacts are expected to far outweigh 
any costs.  
   
Technical Assistance   In  connection  with  the  implementation  of  the  fourth  and  final 
subprogram  of  the  Financial  Sector  Program  II  Cluster,  the 
Government has asked ADB for a capacity development technical 
assistance (CDTA) grant. The proposed CDTA is being processed 
separately.

I.  THE PROPOSAL  
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 3 of the Financial Sector Program II (FSP II).  
 
II.  BACKGROUND 
 
2.  ADB has supported reforms in Cambodia’s financial sector since 1999, beginning with a 
diagnostic  assessment  of  the  financial  sector  and  formulation  of  the  Financial  Sector 
Development  Blueprint  2001–2010.  The  blueprint,  updated  as  the  Financial  Sector 
Development Strategy (FSDS) 2006–2015, was adopted by the Government in February 2007. 
The FSDS provides the long-term objectives and development framework to guide and shape 
medium-term policy design and implementation. The Government has, since 2001, been able to 
implement important reforms in the financial sector with ADB assistance under the first Financial 
Sector Program1 (FSP I) that concluded in August 2007 and with complementary assistance 
from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) poverty reduction and growth facility that ended in 
2003. Since implementation of the blueprint, there have been some notable achievements as 
well as lessons from both domestic and international experience. Those experiences, coupled 
with  the  need  to  support  continuing  development  of  the  financial  sector  to  meet  the  new 
challenges, prompted the Government to request further support from ADB to enable continuing 
reforms in the sector. This led to design and approval of the FSP II cluster2 on 6 December 
2007. 
 
3.  The FSP II comprises a series of four single-tranche subprograms, to be implemented 
from  September  2006  to  December  2010,  within  a  well-defined  medium-term  framework 
involving  fundamental  reforms  to  be  completed  prior  to  consideration  by  ADB’s  Board  of 
Directors  of  each  subprogram.  Subprograms  are  linked  by  key  actions  (triggers)  deemed 
essential for the success of the medium-term program. The overall goal of the FSP II is to 
promote the development of a sound, market-based financial system to enhance resource 
mobilization and support sustainable economic growth. The expected outcome is a growing, 
resilient, and efficient financial system. (The design and monitoring framework for the Program 
is in Appendix 1, including the achievements of subprograms 1 and 2 with TA support from 
ADB. The policy matrix and medium-term program are in Appendix 2.)  
 
4.  Subprogram 1 with 14 key reform actions was approved together with the FSP II cluster 
concept on 6 December 2007. The loan agreement for subprogram 1 (footnote 2) was signed 
on 18 February 2008 and the single tranche equivalent of SDR6,381,000 was fully disbursed in 
April 2008. Subprogram 2 with 14 key reform actions (triggers) was approved on 5 December 
2008 after all policy triggers were completed.3 The loan agreement was signed on 8 December, 
declared effective on 22 December, and the single tranche equivalent to SDR6,618,000 was

implementation of key policy triggers of subprogram 3. With 11 policy triggers and 11 expected 
milestones, implementation of subprogram 3 began in January 2009.  
 
III.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT  
 
5.  Global  economic  crisis  impact  economic  growth.  Cambodia  has  recorded  real 
economic growth of over 9% throughout 2001 to 2008 (country economic indicators for 2004–
2009 in Table 1). With this continuous high economic growth, indications are that the incidence 
of overall poverty declined from 35% in 2004 to an estimated 30% in 2007. However, this gain 
may be reversed if the effect of the global economic slowdown on Cambodia’s economy is 
prolonged and the country’s garment exports, tourism receipts, and foreign funding for large-
scale construction projects continue to fall, as these are three of the four key engines for 
Cambodia’s economic growth. Exports of garments to the US and Europe, tourist arrivals, and 
foreign direct investment have fallen off sharply since the last quarter of 2008, contributing to 
the slowdown in gross domestic product (GDP) growth to 6.7% in 2008. Garment export, which 
accounts for 16% of GDP, declined by 27% in the first 5 months of 2009; receipts from tourism, 
representing 15% of GDP, declined by around 3%; and construction, which accounts for 7% of 
GDP, has slowed down because of the decline in foreign direct investment. Only agricultural 
output (27% of GDP) is expected to show relatively strong growth (estimated at 4.3%) in 2009. 
ADB has revised down economic growth for 2009 to –1.5% (from 2.5%) and projected economic 
growth to pick up moderately to around 3.5% (from 4%) in 2010. As a result, state revenues are 
expected  to  shrink  by  about  1 percentage  point  of  GDP  in  2009,  from  11.9%  in  2008, 
contributing to a larger budget deficit. On a positive note, the inflation rate, which peaked at 
25.1% in June 2008, declined into the single digits early this year (7.5 at the end of August 
2009) in line with lower fuel and food prices and easing domestic demand pressures (Figure 1). 
This provides room for macroeconomic stimulus measures. 
 
6.  Strong but vulnerable external sector. With the projected slowdown in exports and 
services, the external current account deficit widened to 16.5% of GDP in 2008 and is projected 
to narrow to 11.8% of GDP in 2009. The current account deficit will narrow as declining exports 
are expected to be partially offset by lower imports from the reduction in related inputs (fabrics, 
food items, construction materials) and by lower fuel prices, resulting in an estimated overall 
trade balance of –13%. Gross foreign reserves that reached a high of $2.2 billion at the end of 
2008  (4 months  of  import  cover)  have  remained  at  the  same  level  in  June  2009.  In  the 
meantime, the authorities will continue to monitor the situation closely. 
 
7.  Pro-growth fiscal policy. The Government has maintained a prudent fiscal stance over 
recent years and built up its deposits in the banking system to around 6% of GDP. The overall 
budget deficit for 2008 was 2.7% of GDP compared to 2.8% in 2007, mainly financed by 
overseas sources. The 2009 budget, prepared before the onset of the global financial crisis, 
projects an overall deficit of 3%–4% of GDP to be financed from foreign sources combined with 
a drawdown of the accumulated fiscal reserve within the banking system. The Government 
positively considered the IMF’s recommendation to allow the deficit to increase to 4.8% of GDP 
to provide added fiscal stimulus, especially in the wake of lower government revenues in 2009. 
Given the projected economic contraction for Cambodia in 2009, an expansionary budget is 
appropriate to maintain social expenditures, and to stimulate economic growth including through 
higher levels of capital spending. No new fiscal measures were introduced in 2009, and since 
August the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) started receiving proposals from ministries 
for the 2010 budget.

8.  Monetary conditions deteriorate and inflation contained. Fueled by rising foreign 
capital inflows and bank deposits, broad money growth accelerated sharply, peaking at 63% in 
December 2007. This contributed to an unsustainable rate of growth in bank credit, which 
reached 102% year-on-year in May 2008. It also stoked inflation, which had been subdued until 
2007. Inflation was also sparked by supply-side shocks and surged from an annual rate of 
10.8% in December 2007 to peak at 25.1% in June 2008. The monetary authorities responded 
by imposing a 15% limit on bank credit to the real sector in June 2008 (subsequently removed in 
January 2009), by doubling the minimum reserve requirement on foreign currency deposits to 
16% in July of the same year (subsequently reduced to 12% in January 2009), and by easing 
restrictions on placement of excess reserves offshore. Later in the year, food and fuel prices

4   
 
 
declined, and combined with the above monetary policy measures, helped bring down the 
inflation rate to 12.5% in December 2008 and 7.5%4 in August 2009. Inflows of foreign capital 
are projected to decline throughout 2009.

9.  Impact of the global financial crisis on the financial sector and policy responses. 
Cambodia’s financial sector is not directly affected by the global financial crisis, given that there 
is no capital market and the local financial market remains underdeveloped and is not integrated 
into  the  world  or  regional  markets.  However,  Cambodia’s  financial  sector  is  moderately 
vulnerable because of its exposure to the real sectors, which are being affected by the global 
economic downturn, and also through the decline in foreign direct investments. The National 
Bank of Cambodia (NBC), early in the year, took substantive actions in response to emerging 
strains  on  the  banking  system  caused  by  tighter  liquidity  conditions  and  the  slowdown  in 
economic growth. In particular, the removal of the 15% limit on banking credit to the real sector, 
reduction of the minimum reserve requirement from 16% to 12%, the creation of an overdraft 
facility  to  manage  temporary  liquidity  risk  from  individual  banks,  improvements  to  the 
management  of  the  reserve  requirement  system,  adoption  of  the  revised  regulation  to 
strengthen asset classification and provisioning, and the strong commitment to improving the 
regulatory regime, bank surveillance, and enforcement of prudential regulations. Total liquidity is 
gradually improving and in August 2009 broad money supply recovered to 31% growth (year-
on-year) while growth of credit to the private sector is still declining. NBC is monitoring the 
liquidity position of banks and financial institutions on a daily basis and nonperforming loans 
(NPLs) on a monthly basis.   
 
                                                 
4  A new consumer price index methodology was adopted in April 2009 using 2006 as the base year. As a result, the 
consumer price index data since 2006 have been revised.

5   
 
10.  Macroeconomic stability is crucial. Cambodia’s economy is vulnerable to a number of 
adverse developments in the external environment. The sharp slowdown in the US, European, 
and major Asian economies together with recent turbulence in international financial markets 
has indirectly affected growth conditions in Cambodia. Maintaining macroeconomic stability, 
including a low rate of inflation, is a necessary condition for the economy’s diversification and 
growth recovery. Equally important is to limit the adverse impact of the economic slowdown on 
vulnerable segments of society. Cambodia has reserves sufficient for 4 months of imports, and, 
while these are normally adequate against external shocks, close monitoring of macroeconomic 
and financial developments is needed. Beyond the near-term, complementary structural reforms 
will  be  required  to  address  Cambodia’s  longer-term  development  challenges,  especially  in 
reducing poverty (particularly in rural areas) and narrowing urban–rural income disparities. As a 
contribution  to  the  financial  sector,  NBC  and  MEF  are  considering  ways  to  fast-track  the 
adoption of market-based instruments to help absorb excess liquidity whenever required and to 
begin the development of interbank and capital markets. This is consistent with FSDS 2006–
2015 objectives. 
 
IV.  LINK BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT AND ADB STRATEGIES 
11.  Cambodia’s 5-year National Strategic Development Plan 2006–2010 was prepared in 
the context of a falling, but still high, incidence of overall poverty and a growing urban–rural 
divide. The plan aims to give effect to the Government’s Rectangular Strategy (phase 2), 
adopted in October 2008, that sets out the Government’s reform agenda as a series of four 
interlocking strategies with enhanced governance at its core. One of the four strategies focuses 
on the preconditions required to promote economic growth through agriculture, infrastructure, 
and  private  sector  development  while  enhancing  employment  and  human  resource 
development. 
 
12.  ADB’s overarching goal in Cambodia is sustainable poverty reduction. In line with the 
priorities and strategies identified in the Government’s Rectangular Strategy (phase 2), ADB’s 
country strategy and program5 focuses on three strategic pillars: (i) broad-based economic 
growth  through  investments  in  physical  infrastructure,  development  of  the  financial  sector, 
support for greater regional integration, sustainable development of small and medium-sized 
enterprises  (SMEs),  and  investments  in  agriculture  and  irrigation;  (ii)  inclusive  social 
development through basic education, empowerment of vulnerable groups such as women and 
ethnic  minorities,  control  of  communicable  diseases,  provision  of  rural  water  supply  and 
sanitation facilities, and community-based sustainable management and conservation of natural 
resources in the Tonle Sap basin; and (iii) good governance through improvements in public 
financial management to enhance the development effectiveness of public expenditures and 
decentralization initiatives to strengthen local participation in government and improve public 
service delivery.   
 
13.  ADB’s country strategy and program specifically states that ADB will continue its leading 
role  in  supporting  financial  sector  development  and  that  ADB’s  future  involvement  in  the 
financial sector would depend on the successful update of the FSDS. The updated FSDS 2006–
2015 states that financial sector development is not an end in itself; rather, it is one aspect 
supporting the development and reduction of poverty in Cambodia (Figure 2). While much work 
is  needed  to  achieve  this  difficult  goal,  accelerating  and  diversifying  growth  is  generally 
accepted as the key. Financial sector development must support this objective. Reform and 
change are essential for growth. At the same time, expanding finance brings risks. Hence, the

prudential risk reduction, transparency, and uniform application of rules and regulations.

V.  THE FINANCIAL SECTOR 
 
A.  Sector Description and Performance  
 
14.   Following the political instability and institutional destruction of the late 1970s and early 
1980s, Cambodia’s financial system has been undergoing rapid development based on private 
sector participation. At the end of July 2009, the formal financial system comprised NBC, 
27 private commercial banks, 6 specialized financial institutions, 2 representative offices of 
foreign-based  banks,  20  licensed  and  25  registered  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs),  and 
7 insurance companies. Cambodia also has the objective of developing bond and securities 
markets in the near future. The predominantly rural nature of the economy, high transaction 
costs,  and  low  creditor  confidence  have  been  the  main  factors  resulting  in  low  formal 
intermediation  and  outreach  within  the  financial  sector.  There  has  also  been  a  slow 
development of nonbank financial institutions, with a limited range of products and services 
being offered. A sector analysis is in Appendix 3.  
 
15.  The  performance  of  Cambodia’s  financial  sector  has  been  satisfactory,  though 
challenging (refer to key financial data in Table 2). With a relatively strong banking subsector, 
financial deepening has accelerated with increased financial services promoted through the 
progressive reforms implemented under the FSP I and II. The broad money supply (M2) to GDP 
has risen from 20.5% of GDP in 2006 (before the FSP II) to 29.3% of GDP in 2008 (Figure 3). 
Credit to the private sector has correspondingly risen from 12.2% of GDP in 2006 to 23.6% of 
GDP in 2008. Total deposits to GDP was around 22.8% of GDP in 2008 compared to 17.9% of 
GDP in 2006. Despite these positive developments, policy gaps, implementation challenges, 
and capacity constraints still need to be addressed in each of the subsectors. Further, the sector 
is beginning to experience the stress of the indirect effects of the global economic downturn on 
Cambodia’s economy.

16.  Banking.  At  the  end  of  July  2009,  there  were  27  private  commercial  banks, 
6 specialized  banks  (including  one  state-owned  bank—the  Rural  Development  Bank),  and 
2 representative offices of foreign-based banks in Cambodia. Most of the recent performance 
indicators suggest that the banking system is reasonably profitable, efficient, has adequate 
liquidity, and is well capitalized. On average, banks have maintained overall solvency at above 
25% since 2001 (33% in June 2009) compared to the minimum prudential requirement of 15% 
(Figures 4 and 5). Furthermore, the capital requirement for banks that are owned by nonbank 
entities was recently tripled from $13 million equivalent as a precaution against potential shocks. 
The reported NPL ratio of banks has increased from 3.7% in December 2008 to 5.2% in June 
2009. Banks have been free to set their own interest rates since 1995 and the average annual

9   
 
interest rate spread declined from 15.3% in 2004 to 9.8% in June 2009. While substantial 
progress has been made in the banking supervision area, further work is required to upgrade 
prudential requirements fully to international standards and best practices, recruit and upgrade 
the  skills  of  new  NBC  supervision  staff,  and  enhance  proper  surveillance  and  uniform 
enforcement of regulations to maintain the safety of public deposits and the integrity of the 
banking system.

17.  Microfinance. Microfinance has come a long way since licensing commenced in 2002, 
with 20 licensed MFIs and 25 registered nongovernment-operated MFIs at the end of July 2009. 
The microfinance industry is expanding rapidly, providing the link between the formal financial 
sector and rural households and microenterprises (Figure 6). The number of active borrowers 
availing of rural household credits, credit for agriculture, and small-business loans increased 
from 624,000 clients in 2007 to more than 807,335 clients (6% of the total population) in June 
2009, with potential for further growth. Microfinance lending also grew from $160.1 million in 
2007 to $262.5 million in June 2009, with reported NPLs rising from below 1% in December 
2008 to 3% in June 2009. Voluntary savings remain very small and access to local finance by 
MFIs has been very limited. With TA6 from ADB, NBC issued a prakas7 in December 2007 
setting out the criteria for MFIs that are eligible to mobilize voluntary public savings. Two MFIs 
have been granted license to mobilize savings from the public and two other applications are 
being processed. Through NBC’s encouragement, five commercial banks are now providing 
credit facilities to MFIs and other commercial banks are being encouraged to provide this facility 
to help MFIs at a time when the global financial crisis is affecting offshore funding sources.

a  more  comprehensive  legal  and  regulatory  framework  (comparable  to  those  used  in

19.  Legal and supporting infrastructure.  Significant commercial legislation enacted since  
2001 includes laws on insurance, accounting, commercial enterprises, negotiable instruments 
and  payment  transactions,  commercial  arbitration,  secured  transactions,  government  and 
nongovernment securities, insolvency, and combating money laundering and the financing of 
terrorism. Most of the enacted laws have been implemented and training curriculum introduced 
at selected legal faculties to train legal practitioners and judges on these new principles. The 
judicial  system,  including  the  commercial  court  in  Cambodia,  is  being  developed  through 
assistance  from  other  development  partners  led  by  the  United  Nations  Development 
Programme  (UNDP).  The  draft  law  on  commercial  courts  that  is  being  considered  by  the 
Council  of  Ministers  is  based  on  the  UNDP  model.  With  the  enactment  of  the  Law  on 
Commercial Arbitration in 2006 under the FSP I, the establishment of the national arbitration 
center is supported by subprogram 3 with TA8 provided by ADB. 
 
20.  Accounting development. Key accounting and auditing initiatives implemented so far 
include (i) adoption of a law on corporate accounts, their audit, and the accounting profession; 
(ii) establishment of a national accounting council to set and interpret standards; (iii) introduction 
of requirements that international accounting standards and international standards on auditing 
be applied to all companies incorporated in Cambodia; and (iv) establishment of an association 
of accountants and auditors (Kampuchea Institute of Certified Public Accountants and Auditors), 
its bylaws, a code of ethics that complies with the requirements of the International Federation

of Accountants, and committees on education and ethics within the association. In 2005, only 
10 locally  qualified  accountants  were  working  in  the  country.  To  improve  accounting  and 
auditing capacity, the Government has been funding a scholarship scheme to assist at least 
70 candidates annually to meet the required certified public accountant (CPA) accreditation. In 
January 2009, MEF issued a prakas on the promulgation of Cambodian Financial Reporting 
Standards based on the International Financial Reporting Standards. In addition, the National 
Accounting  Council  is  working  on  developing  accounting  standards  for  SMEs  based  on 
international standards and best practice. The World Bank is providing TA to the National 
Accounting Council to help revise and update the accounting law, and review the accounting 
framework to help improve the enforcement of the accounting and auditing standards.  
 
B.  Emerging Challenges and Opportunities  
 
21.  Global financial and economic crisis. The turmoil in international financial markets 
intensified in September 2008 following the failure of important financial institutions in the US 
and Europe, which froze interbank and credit markets around the world and pushed the price of 
risk upward—triggering a global liquidity shortage worldwide. Cambodia’s banks have limited 
direct exposure and the domestic capital and money markets have not been fully developed. 
The  indirect  impact  of  the  global  economic  slowdown  on  Cambodia’s  financial  sector  has 
manifested in two ways: (i) on the liquidity of the banking system, as a result of declining foreign 
direct investments and export receipts; and (ii) on the quality of credit exposure to the real 
sector, which are being affected by declining international and domestic demands. Banks that 
have substantially increased their lending since 2007 are affected. The authorities have eased 
monetary policy by reducing the minimum reserve requirement from 16% to 12%, and made 
available  an  overdraft  facility  to  individual  banks  since  January  2009.  The  reported  NPLs 
increased  from  3.7%  in  December  2008  to  5.2%  in  June  2009  and  are  expected  to  rise 
gradually during the year. The banking system has been resilient, with a strong overall solvency 
position  of  33%  in  June  2009  compared  to  the  minimum  prudential  requirement  of  15%. 
Furthermore, the capital requirement for banks that are owned by nonbank entities was recently 
tripled from $13 million equivalent as a precaution against potential shocks. The authorities and 
ADB  will  continue  to  monitor  financial  and  macroeconomic  developments  closely  during 
subprogram 3.  
 
22.     Underdeveloped commercial and institutional framework. As in other developing 
economies, the fundamental weaknesses that stifle financial sector development in Cambodia 
stem mainly from its underdeveloped commercial and institutional framework, low formalized 
enterprise development, and limited human capacity and technical expertise. Previous decades 
of conflict that destroyed institutional structures and drained or in some instances wiped out 
qualified human resources, followed by a period of international isolation, resulted in weak 
governance and very low public confidence. The transition from a centrally controlled to a 
market-led economy and the speedy implementation of changes creates new forms of risk and 
accompanying opportunities for corruption. The commercial court system is being developed by 
other development partners to help enforce contracts and resolve commercial disputes. This 
should increase public and investor confidence in the sector. Enterprises that have enjoyed 
many years of operating without an established rule of law prefer to remain informal. The 
majority of participants in the real sector are reluctant to enter into any form of formal financial 
transactions for fear of being exposed to the tax authorities. To help mitigate these issues, 
efforts are under way to get the National Assembly to adopt the remaining commercial laws, 
have  the  Government  establish  a  commercial  court  with  supporting  dispute  resolution 
mechanisms, and enhance institutional and technical capacity.

13   
 
23.  Rapid expansion of bank lending. Starting from a relatively small base, credit to the 
private sector has been expanding very rapidly, from a total stock of 12.2% of GDP in 2006 to 
23.6% in 2008. The year-on-year growth rate reached 102% at the end of June 2008 but 
declined to 54% at the end of December 2008. Credit, which is concentrated in a few banks, is 
almost  entirely  collateralized  against  the  real  estate  market.  Some  banks’  assets  are 
increasingly  vulnerable  to  real  estate  risks.  In  early  2008,  NBC  issued  guidelines  to  help 
improve banks’ classification and reporting of exposure to housing, construction, and real estate 
loans. While reported system-wide NPLs remain below 10%, there are concerns about the 
quality of asset classification and reporting. NBC issued in February 2009 a revised regulation 
on loan grading and provisioning by banks, based on the Basel 1 requirements, to help improve 
loan classification and reporting. The rapid credit expansion reinforces the critical importance of 
strong banking supervision and enforcing compliance with prudential regulations while giving 
priority to assessing asset quality. ADB provided TA (footnote 8) to help introduce procedures 
for on-site supervision and provide on-the-job guidance to NBC staff during the comprehensive 
review of the six largest banks under subprogram 3.  
 
24.  Bank  supervision  capacity  to  sustain  bank  soundness.  The  progressive 
development of bank supervision capacity through knowledge transfer is an ongoing process. 
This is expected, given that the financial sector has had to be rebuilt over the past 10 years 
following the internal conflict that destroyed institutional structures and either drained or wiped 
out  human  resources  in  most  sectors.  NBC  continues  to  strengthen  the  supervisory  and 
regulatory framework as it strives to maintain its primary objective of ensuring a safe, sound, 
and stable financial system. Specialized technical support is an ongoing requirement as the 
financial sector takes on new products, services, and adopts new international standards and 
practices.  Regulatory  standards  have  been  gradually  improved  and  relevant  prudential 
regulations added since the establishment of the Bank Supervision Department under FSP I. All 
banks adopted a uniform chart of accounts in 2004 and commenced publishing their annual 
audited financial reports since 2005. An early warning system (Cambodia Off-Site Bank Report 
for Prompt Corrective Action) was introduced in 2007. Additional regulations were added in 
2008 and early 2009 to (i) promote the proper identification of NPLs; (ii) allocate sufficient 
provisions for NPLs, internal governance, and fit and proper tests relating to the competencies 
of bank management and board members; and (iii) combat money laundering and financing of 
terrorism. NBC has requested external auditors of each bank to undertake, in addition to the 
annual external audits, a comprehensive review of loan portfolios to June 2008 and provide their 
opinions on the quality of those portfolios and the application of prudential regulations by the 
end  of  September.  These  developments  are  evidence  that  NBC  is  serious  about  bank 
soundness and has made significant progress to promote market transparency and establish a 
sound  regulatory  and  supervisory  regime  to  enhance  the  integrity  of  the  banking  system. 
Although enforcement of prudential regulations is improving, compliance with those regulations 
remains uneven. In June 2009, the Bank Supervision Department had 61 staff with a minimum 
qualification of a bachelor’s degree in accounting, commerce, economics, or law—25 have been 
assigned to bank off-site and 15 to bank on-site supervision. NBC intends to increase the 
number of supervision staff and enforce compliance during FSP II implementation with TA from 
ADB and the IMF.  
 
C.  Lessons 
25.  Key lessons from the FSP I, subprograms 1 and 2 of the FSP II, and the associated TA 
projects to the sector include the following:

14   
 
 
(i)  Long-term perspective. Adoption of the medium-term blueprint for the financial 
sector meant that the Government had a set of long-term objectives to guide and 
shape  medium-term  policy  design  and  implementation.  Changes  in  the 
underlying  policy  environment  necessitated  an  update  of  the  blueprint.  In 
February 2007, the updated blueprint, known as the FSDS for 2006–2015, was 
adopted. The close consultative process involving the Government, ADB, and 
other  development  partners  strengthened  the  Government’s  ownership  and 
increased the potential for funding agency buy-in.  
(ii)  Flexibility in design. Financial sector reforms are complex and involve major 
changes  to  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  institutional  arrangements, 
financial  infrastructure,  and  human  capacity.  Hence,  sufficient  time  must  be 
allocated  to  program  implementation.  Design  flexibility  is  also  a  key 
consideration. The use of the program cluster approach under the FSP I provided 
the opportunity to refine the proposed policy actions for succeeding subprograms 
to reflect the Government’s achievements, changes in the policy environment, 
and lessons from the previous subprograms. The FSP II has also adopted the 
cluster approach, with each of the four subprograms to be processed annually. 
This provides the flexibility to address new macroeconomic developments and 
emerging risks to the financial sector.  
(iii)  Time lag between adoption of reforms and effective enforcement. The 2009 
independent program performance evaluation review covering the FSP I noted 
the time lag between the implementation of reforms and actual enforcement or 
comprehensive compliance. The delays in enforcement of commercial laws and 
comprehensive  application  of  compulsory  insurance,  the  credit  information 
system,  interbank  market,  and  accounting  and  auditing  standards  were 
specifically mentioned as these could weaken the effectiveness of the overall 
FSP I program. The enforcement of commercial laws, however, relates to the 
development of the judicial system as a whole and involves projects funded and 
implemented by other multilateral and bilateral development partners. The design 
of  the  FSP  II  has  taken  into  account  the  progressive  enforcement  of  the 
remaining reforms toward wider compliance within the sector and has identified a 
program of TA projects to support their implementation.  
(iv)  TA resources. Under the FSP I, the Government adopted legal, policy, and 
institutional measures, many of which were relatively new concepts and therefore 
required  extensive  coordination  and  consultation  to  ascertain  stakeholders’ 
understanding, acceptance, and adoption of the new measures. Substantial TA 
support was necessary to ensure that best practices were incorporated and then 
consolidated throughout implementation to achieve the intended results. The 
FSP  II  has  also  identified  a  program  of  TA  projects  to  help  implement  the 
medium-term  program  and  enhance  compliance  with  completed  activities. 
Individual consultants have been selected not only on merit but also on their 
perceived ability to work well with local counterpart staff and sensitivity to the 
local culture. These criteria are considered essential for successful transfer of 
knowledge. 
(v)  Emerging  risks.  The  transition  from  a  centrally  controlled  to  a  market-led 
economy creates new forms of risk. The presence of international banks, the 
offer of more sophisticated services to depositors (credit and debit cards for 
automatic  teller  machines  and  electronic  funds  transfer  systems),  and  the 
increase in lending demonstrate increasing investor confidence in Cambodia’s 
financial system. With these encouraging developments, however, come new 
risks and challenges—such as lack of discipline over the use of credit cards, lax

15   
 
application  of  credit  underwriting  and  portfolio  management  policies,  and 
inappropriate safety nets for users of electronic cards. Strengthening awareness 
of potential risks within both the public and the financial sectors is therefore 
important. Similarly, new ways of mitigating risks must be pursued.  
   
VI.  THE PROPOSED SUBPROGRAM 
26.  Links between subprograms. Following approval of the FSP II cluster in December 
2007,  the  momentum  of  implementing  the  policy  reforms  within  the  FSP  II  medium-term 
framework has been maintained. As a continuation of reforms initiated under subprograms 1 
and  2,  subprogram  3  has  11  key  reform  actions  (triggers)  that  the  Government  began 
implementing  in  January  2009.  All  have  been  completed  prior  to  Board  circulation. 
Disbursement will follow loan effectiveness. Subprogram 4 has been designed with nine triggers 
and six milestones to continue the policy reforms initiated under subprograms 1, 2, and 3 within 
the  four  broad  objectives  of  the  medium-term  framework  that  are  intended  to  (i)  improve 
confidence  and  financial  intermediation,  (ii)  maintain  financial  stability,  (iii)  promote  good 
governance,  and  (iv)  enhance  the  efficiency  of  the  financial  sector.  Implementation  of 
subprogram 4 will commence in January 2010 and will be processed for Board approval and 
disbursement  in  December  2010.  Reform  measures  may  be  added  to  subprogram  4  as 
necessary within the medium-term framework after duly considering the Government’s social 
and economic achievements and changes in the macro policy environment.   
 
27.  Refined subprogram 3 policy triggers. With changing domestic circumstances and 
developmental  priorities,  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  requested  minor 
modifications to three of the triggers. These minor changes are within the medium-term program 
framework and were endorsed by ADB Management (Table 3).

16   
 
 
A.  Progress in the Implementation of Policy Actions under Subprograms 1, 2, and 3 
1.  Improve Confidence and Financial Intermediation 
a.  1.1: Improve Financial Services and the Payments, Clearance, and     
Settlement System 
28.  A  modernized  payment,  clearance,  and  settlement  system  (PCSS)  is  necessary  to 
improve and expand service outreach, develop money and interbank markets, and support 
macroeconomic  policy  implementation.  The  vast  majority  of  transactions  in  Cambodia  are 
conducted in cash rather than by check, and cash transactions are mainly in US dollars. Checks 
are mainly used by companies and a few individuals who maintain bank accounts and are 
manually  cleared  and  settled  through  clearinghouses  operated  by  NBC  (in  Phnom  Penh, 
Siem Reap, and Sihanoukville, with no electronic link between them). Checks are presented 
each morning at 9:30 a.m. and dishonored checks flow back through the system at 3:00 p.m. 
Settlement from clearing operations is recorded in the NBC books at each branch office. In view 
of the archaic and inefficient way that the current manual system operates, NBC places high 
priority on upgrading the payment and settlement system because it will help build confidence, 
enhance growth in financial intermediation and outreach, and encourage product and service 
innovation. Further, the rapidly growing economy is straining the current manual system; an 
upgraded system is required to support the larger, more complex financial transactions in the 
economy; and moving from the cash-based to a check-based treasury accounts system would 
enhance public financial management capacities throughout government.  
 
29.  In  2005,  Cambodia  enacted  the  Law  on  Negotiable  Instruments  and  Payment 
Transactions, which provides a legal basis for negotiable instruments such as checks, bills of 
exchange,  and  promissory  notes,  plus  regulation  of  payment  systems.  The  process  for 
modernizing the national PCSS started in 2006 when NBC established the Payments Policy 
Unit (PPU). With technical support from ADB, NBC developed a road map for modernizing the 
national  PCSS.  Staff  of  the  PPU  consulted  with  banks  to  obtain  their  input  on  the  unit’s 
initiatives and to garner support for implementing the proposed road map. Under subprogram 1, 
NBC signed a memorandum of understanding with each commercial bank endorsing the road 
map to modernize the national PCSS. NBC implemented key actions of phase I of the road map 
to  modernize  the  national  PCSS  under  subprogram  2  in  2008.  A  prakas  on  check 
standardization was issued by NBC in September 2008 after it was reviewed by all banks. An 
interbank switch was launched in August 2008 between four banks and the shared visa switch 
was considered a positive beginning and may develop into a more inclusive and beneficial 
system in the future. 
 
30.  With a long-term payment expert funded by ADB, the road map to modernize the PCSS 
was updated and adopted under subprogram 3. In addition, NBC has submitted a proposal to 
MEF for funds (about $3.6 million) under FSP II loan proceeds to upgrade the PCSS. An interim 
software  solution  for  check  clearance  was developed  by  the  NBC  IT  Division.  Following 
preliminary tests with banks, the software went live in May 2009, accompanied by a set of rules 
and procedures to regulate clearance and settlement of checks. Since Cambodia presently 
operates a decentralized system, with every bank maintaining both riel and US dollar settlement 
accounts at each provincial NBC, this interim solution is considered pragmatic. The PPU staff 
will continue discussions with commercial banks on ways to improve the efficiency of check 
clearance and settlement, on issues regarding retail mobile phone payments, on an interbank 
switch to handle retail electronic payments, and to identify practical solutions to enhance funds 
transfer and faster bank settlement during subprogram 4. To enhance funds transfer and early

17   
 
settlement,  the  PPU  is  developing  a  credit  remittance  payment  instrument  designed  with 
suitable flexibility to be used as a direct funds transfer instrument; as a direct credit; and as a 
direct debit instrument for government salary payment, utility payments, and settlement between 
banks. The project preparatory TA consultants’ advice on the importance of establishing a real-
time gross settlement (RTGS) system has been deferred because a core requirement of any 
RTGS is that bank settlement accounts are centralized so that the central RTGS has a total 
view, and total management, of the respective commercial bank’s credit and liquidity exposure 
on a real-time basis. Centralization of commercial bank settlement accounts is being planned for 
implementation when the new core banking system is successfully implemented and rolled out 
to all branches near the end of 2010.  
 
b.  1.2: Enhance Consumer Access to Credit and Market Confidence 
31.  To improve the quality of credit underwriting and portfolio management, and to boost 
confidence  in  the  banking  system,  a  credible  credit  information  system  and  supporting 
regulations are needed. With close cooperation between NBC and the Bankers Association, a 
pilot online credit information sharing system (CIS), using negative data, was established in 
August 2006 to support the credit appraisal processes of participating banks. Rules, regulations, 
procedures,  and  a  governing  structure  are  in  place,  but  implementation  has  not  met 
expectations. Participating banks have reported that since introduction of the CIS they have had 
difficulty uploading data and accessing the information online. A number of actions have been 
taken under the Small and Medium Enterprise Development Program9 to improve the software 
system and build steering committee capacity to understand how the system operates. Several 
additions have been made to the system to allow “no cases to report” as a quick option for 
participating  banks,  which  can  then  trigger  a  more  focused  follow-up  by  the  CIS  steering 
committee.  Subprogram  1  helped  familiarize  stakeholders  with  the  system  and  addressed 
important changes to the CIS and its management structure to enhance effectiveness. During 
subprogram 2, NBC continued to help resolve systematic issues related to the CIS and at the 
same time strengthen bank compliance which is a key factor in the effectiveness of the CIS. 
Under subprogram 3, NBC added MFIs into the negative CIS system and plans to upgrade the 
software to include other sources of credit data and explore the possibility of corporatizing the 
CIS during subprogram 4.  
 
32.  The orderly development and expansion of the financial market requires knowledgeable 
customers as well as competent providers of financial services. It requires customers to be able 
to make informed decisions about the services they require and the type of financial institutions 
best suited to oversee their financial transactions. Since 2005, all banks have been required to 
publish their audited financial statements to enable the public to make informed judgments 
regarding where to place their deposits and with which banks to transact. Several banks have 
published these annual audited financial reports on their own websites. Following recent high 
credit  growth  in  the  banking  system,  NBC  requested  all  bank  auditors  to  undertake  a 
comprehensive portfolio review as of the end of December 2007 and June 2008. These audit 
reports  were  completed  by  the  end  of  June  and  September  2008.  Subprograms  2  and 3 
supported NBC in its efforts to promote bank transparency by requiring all audited financial 
statements of banks as well as new prudential regulations to be published on the NBC website.
